column2: De Administrando Imperio
On the Governance of the Empire is a political geography of the world, attributed to Constantine VII. It is a domestic and foreign policy manual for the use of Constantine's son and successor.
Háleygjatal
A skaldic poem by Eyvindr Skáldaspillir, the court poet of King Hákon the Good of Norway. The skald seeks to establish the Hlaðir dynasty as the social equal of the Hárfagri dynasty.
Tarikh-i Tabari

History of the Prophets and Kings is chronicle written by the historian Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari. Beginning with Creation, it concerns Muslim and Middle Eastern history. An appendix was written by Abu Abdullah, a Turk student of al-Tabari.
Chronicon Salernitanum

An anonymous chronicle of the history of the Principality of Salerno. Attributed to Radoald of Salerno, Abbot of San Benedetto. It has some claims to literary merit and the matter is good despite the lack of critical ability which disfigures the work.
Annales Cambriae

Despite the name, the "Annals of Wales" record not only events in Wales, but also events in Ireland, Cornwall, England, Scotland and further afield. The focus of the events recorded especially in the later two-thirds of the text is Wales.
Tractatus Coislinianus

An ancient Greek manuscript outlining a theory of comedy in the tradition of Aristotle's Poetics. It states that comedy invokes pleasure, inducing catharsis. It proceeds to describe the devices used and manner in which catharsis is brought about.
Origo Gentis Langobardorum

A short Latin account offering a founding myth of the Lombard people. The first part visions the origin and naming of the Lombards, and the following text more resembles a king-list, up until the rule of Perctarit.
Legenda Sancti Goeznovii

A hagiography of Goueznou, a Cornish Bishop of Léon in Brittany, who is venerated as a saint in the region around Brest and the diocese of Léon. Includes an unusual preface detailing the Brittonic history and some episodes from Britain's traditional history.
Alf Layla Wa-Layla

One Thousand and One Nights is an Arabic folkloric collection. Collected over centuries by authors, translators, and scholars across all Asia and Africa. Some tales trace their roots back to ancient Arabic, Persian, Greek, Indian, and Turkish folklore.
Historia Regum Britanniae

Chronicles the lives of the Kings of the Britons over the course of two thousand years, beginning with the Trojans founding the British nation and continuing until the Anglo-Saxons assumed control of much of Britain around the 7th century.
Roman de Brut

The Romance of Brut is a verse history of Britain by the poet Wace. Intended for a Norman audience interested in the culture of the new Anglo-Norman territories, it covers the story of King Arthur and the history of Britain back to the mythical Brutus of Troy.
Gesta Berengarii Imperatoris

Deeds of Emperor Berengar details the career of Berengar of Friuli, Emperor of Italy. It follows his career from its inception until his imperial coronation in Rome. It is a court panegyric and highly laudatory of its namesake.
Gesta Danorum

Deeds of the Danes describes Danish history and to some degree Scandinavian history in general, from prehistory onwards. In addition, Gesta Danorum offers singular reflections on European affairs from a unique Scandinavian perspective.
Gesta Hungarorum

Deeds of The Hungarians details the conquest of the Carpathian Basin and the origin of the Hungarians, identifying their ancestors with the ancient Scythians. The author used the Bible, folk songs and ballads when writing his work.
Gesta Principum Polonorum

Deeds of the Princes of the Poles describes Duke Boleslaw III 'Wrymouth', his ancestors, and the Polish principality during and before his reign. Its author is traditionally called Gallus, an Irishman connected with the monastery of St. Gilles.
Rijnlandse Rijmbijbel

The "Rhinelandic Rhyming Bible" is a verse translation of biblical histories, composed in a mixed dialect containing Low German, Old Dutch and High German (Rhine-Franconian) elements. Written in Werden Abbey, near Essen.
Vepkhist'q'aosani

The Knight in the Panther's Skin is a Georgian poem written by Shota Rustaveli. An epic work, it consists of over 1600 Rustavelian Quatrains and is considered to be a masterpiece. A copy of this poem is part of the dowry of any Georgian bride.
Bahramnameh

The Seven Beauties is a romantic epic by Persian poet Nizami Ganjavi, part of the Khamsa. The poem was dedicated to the Ahmadili ruler of Maragha. The poem is a masterpiece of erotic literature, but it is also a profoundly moralistic work.
Lais of Marie de France
A series of twelve narrative Breton lais by the poet Marie de France. The short, narrative poems generally focus on glorifying the concept of courtly love by the adventures of their main characters.
Vetala Panchavimshati
A collection of of niti-sastras (tales of political ethics) involving the semi-legendary Indian king Vikramaditya. Written by a well-educated courtier named Sivadasa.
Færeyinga Saga

This saga of the Faroe Islands, is the story of how the Faroe Islanders were converted to Christianity and became a part of Norway. The author is unknown. According to Dicuil, a Hiberno-Scottish mission, the Papars lived in the Faroes before Vikings came.
Le Roman de la Rose

The Romance of the Rose is a French poem styled as an allegorical dream vision. The work's stated purpose is to both entertain and to teach others about the art of romantic love. Throughout the poem, Rose is used both as the name of the titular lady and as a symbol of female sexuality.
Blanquerna

Blanquerna is a novel written by Ramon Llull. It chronicles the life of its eponymous hero. It is a major work of literature written in Catalan. Details the trials of a nobleman whose heart if conflicted between religion and want of matrimony.
Shu Jing
A collection of documents and speeches allegedly from the Xia, Shang and Western Zhou periods, and even earlier. It contains some of the earliest examples of Chinese prose.
Yi Li
The Book of Etiquette and Ceremonial is a Chinese classic text about Zhou dynasty social behavior and ceremonial ritual as it was practiced and understood during the Spring and Autumn period.
Xiaojing
The Classic of Filial Piety is a Confucian classic treatise giving advice on filial piety: that is, how to behave towards a senior such as a father, an elder brother, or ruler.
Ji Zhong Jinian

The Bamboo Annals is a chronicle of ancient China. It begins at the earliest legendary times of the Yellow Emperor and extends to 299 BC, with the later centuries focusing on the history of the State of Wei in the Warring States period.
Zhan Guo Ce

The Annals of the Warring States recounts the history of the Warring States from the conquest of the Fan clan by the Zhi clan in 490 BC up to the failed assassination of Qin Shi Huang by Gao Jianli in 221 BC.
